primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The movement from self-deception and the 'exhausting charade' of righteousness to the freedom of confession and divine restitution through the cross.

subject.identificatie: God (specifically in the person of Jesus Christ at the climax).
tekstueel_bewijs: God has shown us a great thing.
There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself.
Jesus... has voluntarily taken our place.

object.identificatie: The restoration of the sinner (A clean heart/Righteousness).
tekstueel_bewijs: Create in me a clean heart
that in him we might become the righteousness of God

zender.identificatie: The Holiness and Righteousness of God.
tekstueel_bewijs: the white light of the righteousness of God
God who has the absolute right to make demands
we are not going to be left like naked people in a storm
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer identifies as the Receiver of an action performed by the Subject (Christ).

helper.identificatie: Psalm 51 / The Liturgy of Ash Wednesday.
tekstueel_bewijs: the source of its ageless significance
we are going to read this Psalm together
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject who acts, while the Word (Psalm) acts as the Helper to bring the hearer to the place of reception.
helper.rol_van_geest: Implicit; the 'right spirit' is an indwelling gift.

tekstueel_bewijs: strange imperviousness to the unpleasantness of self-knowledge
the storm of the wrath of God against sin
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just a lack of manners (apology) but the 'hostility of Satan' and the 'wrath of God'.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human act of confession and apology in horizontal relationships.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer (The 'I')
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The sermon uses human examples of confession (O.J. Simpson, South Africa) as a pedagogical entry point, but subordinates them to the theological necessity of God's action.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has shown us a great thing.
Jesus... has voluntarily taken our place.
God made him to be sin.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We lie to others and ourselves.

voorbeelden: desire for forgiveness is such a great thing.
learned to see sin as God sees it
God is truly able to do away with sin.
There is Another who has taken the sentence.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon moves from the human lack of 'Savoir' (blindness) to God's 'Pouvoir' (the Cross). It emphasizes that humans cannot save themselves; only God has the power to 'blot out' offenses.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from ~S1 (Lies) to ~S2 (Nakedness/Confession) and finally to S1 (Grace) because Christ took S2 (Judgment).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ takes the 'Storm' (S2) so the sinner can move from the 'Charade' (~S1) to 'Righteousness' (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High. The 'storm of the wrath of God' is presented as a real cosmic force.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon begins with human examples of confession, it concludes with a robust substitutionary atonement where God is the primary actor.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: It takes maturity, wisdom, and true manliness to offer a handsome apology.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself.
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession of sin.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Initially uses the Count (Figaro) and David as models of confession, but eventually shifts David from 'model' to 'receiver' of God's creation of a clean heart.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon provides its own alternative: David is not the hero of honesty, but the recipient of God's 'loving-kindness'.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the 'exhausting charade' of self-justification.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Justification by faith alone; the hearer is passive in the 'blotting out' of sin.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from horizontal apologies to vertical atonement is seamless and logically grounded in the definition of sin as 'theological'.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'manliness' of apology and the 'nakedness' of the cross.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place, naked in the storm.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit is the 'right spirit' created/renewed by God, not summoned by man.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; it is an offense against the 'white light' of God's holiness.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully shifts the Subject from the 'Confessing Man' to the 'Crucified Christ'.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly high on Savoir (Knowledge) in the first half.
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain the current Pouvoir (Power) focus of the conclusion.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Ensure the 'manliness' of apology is clearly framed as a fruit of grace rather than a prerequisite.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: Strongly identified as the Wrath of God and Satan.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterful example of moving from a psychological/ethical surface to a deep-structural Gospel core.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the O.J. Simpson anecdote's effectiveness; semiotics reveals that anecdote as a 'Secondary Program' that serves the 'Fundamental Program' of Atonement.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains Psalm 51; semiotics explains how the preacher uses Psalm 51 to re-assign the hearer's role from 'Self-Justifier' to 'Pardoned Sinner'.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas's model exposes that the 'Subject' of the sermon's climax is not the person praying the Psalm, but the Christ who fulfills the Psalm's plea.

appendices.notities: The sermon is a classic 'Rutledge' style structure where the human predicament is explored only to be 'interrupted' by the Divine Subject.
